title: 2  Sept-Oct Math Notes - Real Analysis

3 INTRODUCTION
The following are notes for Supplement for the textbook Measure, Integration & Real Analysis by Sheldon Axler.
This week’s notes go over Section A - Complete Ordered Field


4 1 Definition
A field is a set \(\mathbb{F}\) along with operations of addition and multiplication on F that have the following properties (Alex, S):

commutativity: \(a+b = b+a\) and \(ab = ba\forall a,b \in\mathbb{F}\)
associativity: \((a+b)+c = a+(b+c)\) and \((ab)c = a(bc)\forall a,b,c \in \mathbb{F}\)
distributive property: \(a(b+c) = ab + ac,\thinspace \forall a,b \in \mathbb{F}\)
additive identity: There exists an element 0 \(\in F\) such that \(a+0=a, \thinspace \forall a \in \mathbb{F}\)
additive inverse: \(\forall a \in \mathbb{f}\), there exists an element \(-a \in \mathbb{F}\) such that \(a+(-a)=0.\)
multiplication identity: There exists an element \(1 \in \mathbb{F}\) such that \(1 \neq 0\) and \(a1=a, \thinspace \forall a \in \mathbb{F}.\)
multiplication inverse: \(\forall a \in \mathbb{F}\) with \(a \neq 0\), there exists an element \(a^{-1} \in \mathbb{F}\) such that \(aa^{-1}=1.\)

0.3 properties of the additive inverse in a field

for each \(a \in \mathbb{F},\thinspace\) the additive inverse of \(a\) is unique (thus the notation \(-a\) makese sense)
\(-(-a) = a\) for each \(a \in \mathbb{F}\)
\((-1)a = -a, \thinspace \forall a \in \mathbb{F}\)

Proof (0.3)
Part (a) We have the additive inverse property: \[a + (-a) = 0\] Suppose there exists an additive inverse of \(a = b, \thinspace b \neq -a. \thinspace\) We have: \[a + b = 0\] Add LHS and RHS by \((-a)\): \[a+b + -a = -a\] Using additive property of \(a +(-a) = 0\): \[0 + b = -a\] \[\rightarrow b = -a\] Impossible since \(b\neq (-a). \thinspace\) So additive inverse of \(a = -a\) is unique.
Part (b) We have the additive inverse property: \[a + (-a) = 0\] Subtract LHS and RHS by (-a): \[ a + (-a) - (-a) = 0 - (-a)\] \[ a = -(-a)\]
Part (c) We have 1 and the additive inverse of 1 = (-1) (Additive Inverse property) We have: \[1 + (-1) = 0\] Multiply LHS and RHS by a:\[a1 + (-1)a = 0a\] Using multiplication identity \(a1 = a\) and \(a0 = 0\): \[a +(-1)a = 0\] \[\rightarrow (-1)a = -a\]
analogous properties of the multiplication inverse

for each \(a \in \mathbb{F},\thinspace\) the multiplication inverse of \(a\) is unique (thus the notation \(a^{-1}\) makese sense)
\((a^{-1})^{-1} = a\) for each \(a \in \mathbb{F}\)
\(1 : a = a^{-1}, \thinspace \forall a \in \mathbb{F}\)

Part (a) We have the multiplication inverse property \(aa^{-1} = 1\) Suppose there exists a multiplication inverse of \(a=b, b \neq a^{-1}\). We have \[ab = 1\] \[\rightarrow ab = aa^{-1}\] Divide LHS and RHS by a: \[b=a^{-1}\] Impossible since \(b \neq a^{-1}\). So the multiplication inverse of any \(a\) is unique.
Part (b) We have the multiplication inverse property: \[aa^{-1} = 1\] Raise LHS and RHS to \(-1\) \(a\): \[(aa^{-1})^{-1} = 1^{-1}\] \[\rightarrow a^{-1}(a^{-1})^{-1} = 1\] Using multiplication inverse property: \[a^{-1}(a^{1})^{-1} = aa^{-1}\] Divide LHS and RHS by \(a^{-1}\): \[(a^{-1})^{-1} = a\]
Part (c) We have the multiplication inverse property: \[aa^{-1} = 1\] We have: \[a^{-1} = a^{-1}\] \[a^{-1}1 = a^{-1}\] Using multiplication inverse property: \[a^{-1}(aa^{-1}) = a^{-1}\] Using associativity property: \[(a^{-1}a)a^{-1} = a^{-1}\] We have \((aa^{-1}) = (a/a) = a\) \[\Rightarrow (a/a)a^{-1} = a^{-1}\] \[(aa^{-1})/a=a^{-1}\] \[\rightarrow 1/a=a^{-1}\].
3 Suppose $ is a field and \(a,b \in \mathbb{F}\). Prove that \((-a)(-b)=ab\).
Proof We have the additive inverse property: \[a+(-a)=0\] Multiply LHS and RHS by b: \[(a+(-a))b=0b\] \[ab+(-a)b=0\] \[ab = -(-a)b\] \[\rightarrow ab = (-a)(-b)\]
4 Suppose \(\mathbb{F}\) is a field and \(a,b,c \in \mathbb{F}\) with \(b \neq 0\) and \(c \neq 0\). Prove that \[\frac{ac}{bc} = \frac{a}{b}\]
Proof We have: \[\frac{ac}{bc} = (ac)(bc)^{-1} = ac(b^{-1})(c^{-1})\] \[\rightarrow \frac{ac}{bc} = a(c^{1}c^{-1})b^{-1}\] \[\rightarrow \frac{ac}{bc} = a1\frac{1}b = \frac{a}{b}\]
5 Suppose \(\mathbb{F}\) is a field and \(a,b,c \in \mathbb{F}\) with \(b \neq 0\) and \(c \neq 0\). Prove that \[\frac{a}{b}-\frac{c}{d}=\frac{ad-bc}{bd}\]
Proof We have: \[\frac{a}{b}-\frac{c}{d} = ab^{-1} - cd^{-1}\] Using multiplication identity \(a1 = a\): \[\rightarrow \frac{a}{b}-\frac{c}{d} = ab^{-1}1 - cd^{-1}1 \] Using multiplication inverse property with \(dd^{-1}\) and \(bb^{-1}\) \[\frac{a}{b}-\frac{c}{d} = ab^{-1}dd^{-1} - cd^{-1}bb^{-1}\] \[\frac{a}{b}-\frac{c}{d} = (b^{-1}d^{-1})(ad - cb)\] \[\frac{a}{b}-\frac{c}{d} = (ad-cb)(bd)^{-1} = \frac{ad-cb}{bd}.\]
Block math:
\[
\int_0^\infty e^{-x^2} \, dx = \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}
\]
<Aligned steps:
\[
\begin{align}
f(x) &= x^2 + 2x + 1 \\
     &= (x+1)^2
\end{align}
\]>
6 Suppose \(\mathbb{F}\) is a field and \(a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{F}\) with \(b \neq 0\) \(c \neq 0\), and \(d \neq 0\). Prove that \[\frac{a}{b} \div \frac{c}{d} = \frac{ad}{bc}\] Proof We have: \[\frac{a}{b} \div \frac{c}{d} = ab^{-1}(cd^{-1})^{-1} = ab^{-1}c^{-1}d\] Using associativity property: \[ab(c^{-1}d^{-1}) = ad(cd)^{-1} = \frac{ad}{cd}\]
